abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the First Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit for Sri Lanka were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            findings and implications show that the recent political
            developments reinforce the importance of linking the release
            of Poverty Reduction Strategy Credit (PRSC) funds to the
            effective implementation of up-front actions and not to
            future promises. Recent poverty numbers, which show a sharp
            increase in inequality between 1990-91 and 2002, also
            reinforce the need to focus on pro-poor reforms, e.g.,
            welfare reforms and rural development. It is important that
            future PRSC operations be more closely linked to the budget.
            In this regard, the Bank team is working with the MOF to
            enhance the policy orientation of the budget through the
            development of a medium term budget framework. To ensure the
            sustainability of reforms, the new government needs to be
            encouraged to enhance consultations with relevant
            stakeholders, including those within the government, and to
            inform the public at large of the pros and cons of reforms,
            perhaps through a more systematic communications strategy.
            Given the difficulties in passing legislative changes, which
            in Sri Lanka's context could be subject to court
            challenges, future operations will need to explore
            alternative (more pragmatic) options to achieve stated objectives.
